name: Fighter Dwarven Defender Weapon Master Challange
author: KidMiracleman

posts.author: KidMiracleman
posts.content:
I have started a Fighter DD WM and I was wondering where I should go with it.  Right now she is at 7 fighter 7 WM and 26 DD
but with 20 levels yet to go to 60 I am not sure what the best balance would be.  I was going to just do the rest DD but now I am not so sure

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: 4 more DD levels for the 3 additional DR and the rest FTR to take EWS, SEWS & LEWS David. What feats remain take Great STR's.

posts.author: KidMiracleman
posts.content: Sounds good.  Thank you

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
This is interesting...I remember my first posted build - Grim Stonefoot (Fighter 10/ DwD 23/ WM 7) - taking some flak from Max Kane (I know, I risk waking the slumbering beast) for essentially using WM as cheese, and its lack of synergy with DwD. Now, I recognise that there was a valid point insofar as I wasn't optimizing DwD as far as DR was concerned, but I still contend that WM was a perfectly acceptable 3rd class - I should probably have dropped some Fighter levels, or at least put some boosts into CON. Of course, in a level 60 environment, that can be easily addressed. And that, really, is my gripe with a 60 level build - one can get everything one wants for Christmas, and the art of the builder becomes diminished.

This is in no way intended as a slight upon the particular environment or players thereon, merely me banging on about more not necessarily meaning better.

(Of course, if we'd all grown up in a level 60 scenario, I'd be singing a different song, and bewailing level 80 builds. As it stands, though, we didn't. So, irrationally, parp.)

Regardless, I love the concept - nothing stirs the heart more than a vexed Dwarf with access to an axe or hammer! I forget who's tagline it was, but I did like (and I paraphrase): "Your god was nailed to a cross. My god carries a hammer. Need I say more?"

posts.author: KidMiracleman
posts.content: I hate to ask this but what do you mean by cheese??

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
KidMiracleman wrote: I hate to ask this but what do you mean by cheese??
I'm sure someone will correct me if I get this wrong, but essentially it's because everything tastes better with cheese on it, even when cheese isn't an integral part of the meal. More traditionally, in a NwN context, it's used when you take 1-3 levels of Monk in a build, just to get Evasion and a bit of speed.

No one's ever explained the expression to me, so I'm just basing this on the context in which I've seen it used before in a desperate attempt to earn kewl points!

posts.author: KidMiracleman
posts.content: Ah...When I first started playing on servers like Tornado of Souls the popular thing people liked to do is add 2 levels of SD or rogue or monk for the evasion.  I thought that was just the way things were done.  I later on decided to experiment with other combinations like Fighter Barbarian DD or Fighter WM DD.  I was criticized for not have evasion. Good times  :)

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I would say the original (or one of the very best at least) cheese example was the "Exalted Sorceress" back from 03' when she used 1 lvl of Monk to achieve full tumble & discipline skills plus evasion and 1 lvl of Paladin to get a massive (+10/ +16) boost in her saving throws, while losing no bonus feat (last one was in 38th) from her list.

Edit: In fact, if she had taken the Paladin lvl near the end, she could have a tremendous Taunt skill as well, but that wasn't in her plans.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Indeed - and Max himself, in his first build here (back in 2011), had the chutzpah to call that build "Holy Weapon Master With Cheese" (Paladin 26/ Weapon Master 13/ Monk 1).

posts.author: KidMiracleman
posts.content: I remember that build.  I remember somebody with cheese in their login name too
